ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: like a herd of yellow camels.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: which seem as though they are yellow-coloured camels.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: As if they were Sufr camels.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: As if they were tawny camels.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: (Or) as it might be camels of bright yellow hue.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: and as bright as a herd of yellow camels.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: As though they were camels yellow tawny.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: As if there were (a string of) yellow camels (marching swiftly)."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: As if they were Jimalatun Sufr (yellow camels or bundles of ropes)."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: As if they were yellow camels.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: As if they were yellowish [black] camels.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [77:33] as if they were [dark] yellow camels (jimālātun is the plural of jimalatun, the plural of jamalun; a variant reading has jimālatun), in terms of their shape and colour. In hadīth [it is stated], ‘The sparks of humans [thrown into the air by the Fire] are black as pitch (qīr)’; the Arabs call dark camels sufr, ‘yellow’, because a touch of yellow is mixed with their blackish colour, and therefore it is said that ‘yellow’ in this verse [actually] means ‘black’, on account of what has been mentioned; but some say no [to this interpretation]; (sharar is the plural of sharāra; qīr is qār, ‘pitch’).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: ((Or) as it might be camels of bright yellow hue) black camels.
